name: samhayler
text: The poo was Mexican magical realist poo.

name: echidnaboy
text: Just like olden times!

name: saulbellow
text:
In olden times, Onstad would never have written such a hastily-patched-together shortcut line as "I kinda wish Charley and me were back home already and I was wipin' this dog off on clean, wet grass."

It's basically present-tense exposition. Is there even a word for that?

name: aperson
text: But he has to say if for it to be a wish, which is granted by the Made in Mexico tag, which apparently grants wishes.

name: saulbellow
text: I know, that's the exposition part - it's awkwardly inserted into the dialogue like exposition often is.

name: hbaranov
text: I felt the exposition deep in my bones, knowing that like all exposition, it wasn't as good as those in the old days.

name: fancypants
text: It's sheep shite, not dog excerment. Not like olden times. It's like celebrating a birthday party but with people you're strangely unfamiliar with. The scene and occasion is the same, but the atmosphere is all different .

name: scorpio_nadir
text:
Quote:
It's sheep shite, not dog excerment.


In Wales, better known as Chucked Berries.

name: stereo
text: Not to be confused with chuckleberries.

name: madnes
text: Not to be confused with Chucklebot.

name: senseihollywood
text: ...or the guy who does the duckwalk and plays Johnny B. Goode.

name: gunsofray
text: not to be confused with Chucklevision

name: aperson
text: I suppose the wish could have been in Ray's head, without being shown as a speech bubble, and then he'd have fizzled out with no exposition.

name: saulbellow
text: Exactly, Yon Good Man.

name: aperson
text: Thereby confusing the fuck out of all but the most cleverest of achewoodians.

name: fermatprime
text: But isn't that the point ?

name: aperson
text: That's not confusing at all. It's obvious what's happening there.

name: woodenteeth
text: I think the only hole in this theory is that thinking in comicland is denoted by a thought bubble or thinkin'cloud.

name: aperson
text: Agh you are right, woodenteeth. With this wishing idea, Onstad has doomed us to understanding what is going on. There is simply no way to avoid Exposition and thus Do The Webcomic Story Right.

name: i_love_kate
text: Except maybe Planning It Out Properly From Day One.

name: woodenteeth
text:
Don't cramp his creativity maaaaaaaaaan.*

* I aggree. Time he got his plan on.

name: steerpike66
text: Which, I have to say, is a disappointing general magical thing for a poncho to do. Granting wishes is very blah, as opposed to the camera that shows you how you feel about yourself of the raining-inside RV.

name: greenkoolayd
text: or?

name: plummet
text: The RV with rain inside must be for mermaids or something

name: i_love_kate
text: It is so that British people can feel at home in any country. Not that any British person would have any idea what an "RV" is.

name: belgand
text:
It is about how he can never truly escape. He wants to go camping, but indoors. The RV has shown him that the wild cares not and will bring the outdoors inside to him. Not just the sunny, pleasant outdoors he wants, but a cold, grey downpour.

Mexican Magical Realism is all about confronting hard truths, poignant realizations, and getting dicked around emotionally.

name: joeynarcotic
text: I love The Beatles, but not when their music is sung by karaoke-level kids in an overblown mess of a movie. It sucks.

name: srikamaraja
text:
Agreed. Terrible.
"See? The Vietnamese women singing 'Jai Guru Deva' are painted white and fall into the water! Get it? Innocence and transformation! I'm sure glad I took an English class, or I'd know this sucks!"

name: gormster
text:
I recommend watching Across the Universe, with the following stipulations:

1. Ignore the plot. Completely. It's stupid and awkward and they force it to fit the lyrics. Don't ignore the performances, which are for the most part pretty good.
2. That said, there is the occasional bad peformance, occasional bad arrangement and occasional bad vocal. There is, at times, cheese. Deal with this, and know that it never lasts too long.
3. Watch it in HD with good surround sound. This is vitally important.

It's a little like The Wall in that if you watch it as a movie, you're going to be disappointed.

name: belgand
text: I recommend watching "Titus" instead. It is the only decent thing (including the wretched Lion King) Julie Taymor has ever done. Which is interesting because it's entirely awesome.

name: srikamaraja
text: Damn. Yes. Hopkins is amazing in his classical element.

name: joeynarcotic
text: Titus is fantastic, but I also like Frida a lot.

name: joeynarcotic
text:
Nah man, The Wall is like a good music video for a whole album. Across the Universe is closer to Moulin Rouge , trying to string together a story out of a bunch of mostly unrelated pop songs. Except Moulin Rouge did it better.

For an earlier look at the same idea applied to Beatles music about 30 years earlier, watch the Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band movie. And when I say watch it, I mean burn your eyes out rather than watch it. It makes Across the Universe look like Picnic Panic Two , yo.

name: tekende
text: If you want to see a good Beatles movie, watch A Hard Day's Night . That movie is most excellent. Pitch-perfect comedy.

name: mattylite
text: Yes!  I just re-saw it recently, and loved the hell out of it.  Every single one of those fuckers is a pretty damn good comedic actor.  Especially John and Ringo.

name: joeynarcotic
text: Most def. Help is patchy and dated, Magical Mystery Tour is stoned hippie self-indulgence, but Hard is fucken wicked.

Joy of joys, I cannot wait.

name: hatstand_mcq
text: I'm afraid I expressed myself badly. I'm not saying that a meal should not be an enjoyable event. I'm saying that it is folly to try and make the actual food you eat during your meal 'fun'. I'm not attacking the idea of cheerful and lively mealtimes, I'm objecting to chicken dippers, mini burgers and stuffed crust pizza: food for people who don't have the attention span to wield a knife and fork simultaneously.

name: hatstand_mcq
text: When I was a small child I once ordered a pudding that was pictured on the menu in the shape of Pingu. In my innocence I thought that the whole construction was forged from ice cream and chocolate. When it arrived it was a plastic container in the shape of a penguin, and inside was a single scoop of vanilla ice cream, partially melted. I watched my friends tuck into gigantic banana splits, and Knickerbocker glories, and I vowed 'never again'.

text: See, my love for Achewood allows me to recognize when it is suffering. If you love something, you don't want it to become devalued. I don't want Achewood to become no good. Therefore, I WILL voice my concerns.

name: gladi8orrex
text: ur conceerns dont mean shit so stuff it, gay boy

name: karljw
text: who says "vajay" aside from 9 year olds?

name: sick_cat
text: when will our culture realize that 30 year old men making jokes about 9 year old vajayjays is inappropriate!!!!  You all owe an apology to all 9 year old vajayjays!!!

name: sick_cat
text:
but seriously if you all are going to discuss this you need to separate the complaints about the quality from the complaints about the timeliness! Quality and timeliness are generally two separate discussions, except that quality is often in many endeavors incompatible with timeliness.
Motherfucking Garfield was on time every day for decades. So was Cathy! and Marmaduke. And my boner in the morning! Okay wait that last one is a bad example.

As for complaints about the timeliness, I have a suggestion... maybe go read a fucking book or something.

name: stereo
text: I personally would be happier to be surprised when a new strip comes than to have a couple days of "I swear, it's almost finished" which is inevitably postponed at least a day from the original time stated.

name: lateadopter
text:
I always know when it will not be done (i.e., the time/date when Onstad puts up a note saying it will be done), therefore I am not annoyed when it is not done at the time I did not expect it. Instead, I am pleasantly surprised on the rare occasions when a strip appears with no warning (Saturday nights, usually) or with warning.

If that is relatively impenetrable, thank you.

name: stonecrab
text: Look, Onstad is an artist.  Can't ya just maybe cut him some slack? I'm telling you ain't nobody gettin' burned on this deal - know why? He is GIVING you a damn GIFT with every fucking strip you read on this FREE site!! (Sorry, but i'm startin' to get pissed off...) And, dammit you just don't complain about gifts.  Dammit.

name: lucidz
text: I'm glad to see more and more people are getting fed up with the descending quality and continued tardiness of the comic.  I think no one here wants the comic to suck.  Most of us have been coming here for years and are faithful to it.  But its dissapointment after dissapointment after dissapointment after...

name: gladi8orrex
text: A comment left by gladi8orrex was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by chivalress, ike, SkiddyFisk)

name: skiddyfisk
text: Hear. I once considered this webcomic the pinnacle of its art, now it's slowly becoming Megatokyo with more cat cocks.

name: desert_donkey
text: did you mean ".. pussy cocks"?

name: gladi8orrex
text: quit ur belly-achin', shit

name: tetsujin
text: Being a jerk is okay if the basic argument you support is either in favor of the comic's current direction, or against those who don't appreciate it.

name: gladi8orrex
text: man fuck you, don' act lik u no me

name: tetsujin
text:
I'm not acting like I know you.

Also, you may find that I'm not acting like I want to know you...

name: gladi8orrex
text: i'll fuck you rite off ur highhorswe u piece o shit. quit frontin' lik u better den eery1 else, shit

name: sick_cat
text: NO!

name: deus
text:
OK! Look here im dissapointed.

I was imagining that Little Nephew and Ray would form two camps bringing in the way of modern Gomorrah, pieace by pieace.

But it just went to me ex machina!

name: tetsujin
text: Ah, that would've been fun.  Somehow I think the resulting fracas would wind up referencing "Braveheart" - but the idea of Ray's quest to find Charley resulting in, I don't know, some kind of difficulty - that could have been pretty cool.

name: srikamaraja
text:
Has no one else reflected upon this being the one true reason that Ray, Ray of Light, Reigning King of Men, is from...

History!

name: lateadopter
text: Second true reason. First was this arc .

name: srikamaraja
text: Damn. I knew what I had missed before I clicked.

name: gunsofray
text: <strike>Me.</strike>  A horny drunk Welshman?

name: gunsofray
text: Now how did my comment get all the way down here? i believed i screwed up yet again..
